justification: Study 1a states that participants "rated these videos on a 5-point Likert scale, ranging from 'not at all' to 'extremely' enjoyable," linking the enjoyment construct to this scale.

In Study 1b the authors write: "In response to the question 'How much did you enjoy the video?' using a 7-point Likert scale (1 = 'not at all'; 7 = 'a great deal'), participants indicated they found the video quite enjoyable."
For Studies 2a-c, the procedure notes that after each clip "participants … rated their enjoyment on a 9-point Likert scale," directly operationalizing enjoyment with that measure.

Study 1c assessed feelings with the prompt "How did you feel while watching the video?" using a 7-point Likert scale (1 = "extremely bad"; 7 = "extremely good"), thus measuring emotional valence with this scale.

Supplementary materials note that participants "circled all of the emotions that they had felt while watching the video, from a list of 20 adjectives," indicating that discrete emotional experience was gauged with this adjective checklist.
The text reports "All connection questions were combined into a composite before analysis (alpha = .819)," showing that feelings of connection were indexed with this composite scale.

measured_by: Monetary Choice Task (Share vs Solo decisions)
justification: Study 2 explains that participants "made a series of choices that allowed us to measure how much money they were willing to forgo (if any) to share an experience," identifying the Monetary Choice Task as the measurement of sharing motivation.

measured_by: point of subjective equivalence (PSE) from choice task
justification: To quantify value, the authors "calculated the point of subjective equivalence (PSE) between the two options for each participant," specifying PSE as an index of the motivation construct.

Study 2b notes that "participants were asked to make a single rating after all trials to indicate how much they enjoyed participating in the experiment; they made this overall enjoyment rating using a 9-point Likert scale."
